raw_text:
Downloads enter US singles chart
 
 Digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time.
 
 Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year.
 
 Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the Pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to US radio stations which play chart music. In addition to Green Day, other artists in the current US digital sales top 10 include Kelly Clarkson, The Game and the Killers.
 
 Sales of legally downloaded songs shot up more than tenfold in 2004, with 200 million track purchased online in the US and Europe in 12 months, the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) reported last month. In the UK sales of song downloads overtook those for physical singles for the first time at the end of last year. The last week of December 2004 saw download sales of 312,000 compared with 282,000 physical singles, according to the British Phonographic Industry. The UK's first official music download chart was launched last September, compiling the most popular tracks downloaded from legal UK sites - including iTunes, OD2, mycokemusic.com and Napster. Westlife's Flying Without Wings - a 1999 track reissued for the occasion - was the first number one of the UK download chart.
 
 A spokesman for the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) said the first combined UK download and sales chart was due to be compiled "within the first half of this year". "Work is going on across the music business right now to make sure the new chart works to plan," he said. The BPI spokesman described the UK music download chart, compiled by the Official Charts Company, as having been "a great success" since its launch. "It has provided a focus for the industry and has really driven interest in downloads among music fans," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Digital music downloads are being included in Billboard's Hot 100 chart for the first time, replacing a separate download chart. Sales of digital music in the US will now be incorporated into this new chart along with sales of physical singles and airplay information. This is the second combined chart to include data from downloads: the Pop 100 and the UK Singles Chart.
llama3.2:3b: Digital music downloads are being included in the US singles chart for the first time, incorporating data from sales of music downloads, physical singles, and airplay information. The UK will also include digital sales in its singles chart later this year. Digital sales shot up tenfold in 2004, with 200 million tracks purchased online in the US and Europe, and sales of song downloads overtook those for physical singles in the UK at the end of last year.
gemma2:2b: Billboard's Hot 100 chart now includes data from digital music downloads. The chart combines sales of physical singles, airplay information, and digital sales. A new Pop 100 chart also uses airplay, digital, and physical sales but only considers US radio station airplay.  Sales of legally downloaded songs have increased significantly in recent years, and UK download charts have become popular.  The UK's first official music download chart is expected to be released later this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The US singles chart includes digital music sales for the first time. Digital music sales will now be tallied with physical songs, radio airplay information and legal song downloads. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) reported that UK download sales overtook those for physical singles in November 2004.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Digital music downloads are now included in the US singles charts, replacing an earlier separate download chart; sales of legally downloaded songs rose significantly from 2004 to 2005; digital sales contribute to Billboard's Hot 100 chart, which will integrate physical single and airplay data for its new Pop 100 chart.
qwen2.5:3b: Digital music downloads are now included in Billboard's main US singles chart for the first time. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently at number two on both the pop and digital charts. Digital sales are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales, which will be combined with physical singles and airplay information into its new Hot 100 chart. The Pop 100 combines all three formats but only includes US radio play data. In 2004, US song downloads increased over tenfold to 200 million tracks sold. UK download sales surpassed physical singles for the first time last year, with Westlife's Flying Without Wings topping the UK download chart. The BPI aims to launch a combined download and sales chart in half of this year, following its successful launch as a download-only chart.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and to the point, preserving key ideas and details from the original text. It provides a brief overview of the main points:

1. Digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time.
2. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of digital downloads.
3. Downloads are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year.
4. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart.
5. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Pop 100 chart, which combines airplay, digital and physical sales information.
6. Sales of legally downloaded songs shot up more than tenfold in 2004, with 200 million track purchased online in the US and Europe in 12 months. In the UK sales of song downloads overtook those for physical singles for the first time at the end of last year. The last week of December 2004 saw download sales of 312,000 compared with 282,000 physical singles, according to the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
7. The UK's first official music download chart was launched last September and compiled the most popular tracks downloaded from legal UK sites - including iTunes, OD2, mycokemusic.com and Napster. Westlife's Flying Without Wings - a 1999 track reissued for the occasion - was the first number one of the UK download chart.
8. Work is going on across the music business right now to make sure the new chart works to plan, said the BPI spokesman. The BPI spokesperson described the UK music download chart as having been "a great success" since its launch.

Digital downloads are now included in the US singles chart, transitioning Billboard's Hot 100 to incorporate both digital and physical sales data, with Green Day leading at number two. The UK will also have a new chart integrating digital and physical sales, launching last September under IFF's report of high US download sales. The UK first officially launched its music downloads chart with Apple Music, featuring top hits like Westlife's reissue.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US singles chart now includes data from download sales, previously only assigned to a separate download chart, and incorporates digital sales into its main chart. The new chart combines airplay information from radio stations which play chart music with physical singles sales figures and tracks sold online in the US and Europe. The first official UK music download chart was launched last year, compiling the most popular tracks downloaded from legal UK sites including iTuNS, OD2, mycoKemiUSmusic.com, and Napster. Westlife's Flying Without Wing was the first number one of the UK download chart. The BPI spokeman described it as "within the first half of this year" to compile a new combined UK download and sales chart. The chart is expected to debut in the second half of this year, with work currently ongoing for its creation across the music industry.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The first combined UK download and sales chart will be compiled within the first half of this year. The BPI is working on making sure that the new chart works as planned. The Official Charts Company has been gathering airplay, digital and physical sales data for their separate charts since 2003, but these numbers were not incorporated into the UK singles chart until this year. With download sales increasing exponentially in the US and Europe, it is expected that artists from across multiple industries will start incorporating them into their chart rankings.

The UK is set to follow suit with their own combined digital download and sales chart later this year, and song sales have skyrocketed tenfold in the US and Europe in 2004. Westlife's Flying Without Wings re-issue became the first number one on the UK's first official music download chart.

A separate digital chart, the Pop 100, has been created to focus on US radio stations that play chart music. Sales of legally downloaded songs shot up more than tenfold in 2004, with 200 million track purchased online in the US and Europe in 12 months, according to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI). In the UK, sales of song downloads overtook those for physical singles for the first time at the end of last year, and the UK's first official music download chart was launched last September.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Digital music downloads are being integrated into Billboard's US singles chart, combining data from sales, physical singles, and airplay. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" leads the Hot 100 and its digital counterpart. Similarly, the UK's first official music download chart is expected to launch by mid-year, merging download sales with physical and airplay data. Download sales have surged, reaching 200 million in 2004, with downloads overtaking physical singles sales in the UK at the end of that year. The US first official digital download chart was launched in September 2005, with Westlife's "Flying Without Wings" as its inaugural number one. Both charts aim to increase interest and focus on digital music sales.
